9.14.17  2:36 pm   Hi! Forgive me if you've explained all this already. But, when you first stated recording the footage for what would eventually become your reality page...did you know from the very beginning that down the road you wanted to edit it (and in some cases add graphics and visuals) and release it? 

     the idea was always in my mind, even since before then when i was only using text

9.14.17  2:13 pm   Hi Bill! I was hoping you could maybe give me some tips on this. So, I play in a band with 2 guitarists (me being one of them). And for certain little sections in certain songs, I want to figure out a way to intertwine the rhythms of the 2 guitars in a way where it sounds like just 1 guitar, but with like a delay/echo type thing. Do you think if I play the same part the other guitarists plays, but slide the whole phrase forward like a 16th note (or maybe an 8th note?) that would kind of give it that delay/echo type sound? I don't have any recording equipment at home to experiment with.. but do you think this technique would work? Any tips or advice on how to make it sound extra crisp and natural? 

     if you are talking about live playing, i don't think this is a reasonable strategy. it sounds more like a fun/impressive stunt that would require a lot of practice to do it right "AMAZING, watch 2 guitar players emulate a delay pedal, just by playing at slightly different times!" not worth it. a fun stunt maybe, but not a good strategy. if you're talking about recording it, sure you could shift one track a little later and make it a little quieter with a little more reverb, but it would still be much easier to use a delay effect. very easy to get access to one. perhaps even easier than getting access to recording equipment, which is also easy

9.14.17  1:26 pm   Can something be challenging without also being interesting? Can something be interesting without also being challenging?

     yes

9.14.17  1:09 pm   Can you play 32nd notes accurately in a 90bpm tempo?

     sure

     I know if you're using a drum machine or programming drums you can make any rhythm you want... but otherwise does 32nd notes really just mean "play this as fast as you can even if it's not actually 1/32 of the beat"

     no, it means 8 notes per beat. actually it means 8 notes per quarter note. or 32 notes per bar, of 4/4

9.14.17  12:41 pm   If I'm at a concert and the band is playing a funky groove where they're accenting the first and third beats of the bar... am I supposed to clap on 1 and 3? Or do I still clap on 2 and 4? 

     1 and 3 and try to get the rest of the audience to switch to that too

9.13.17  3:39 pm   hey bill, can you help me figure out what the time signatures to this song are? https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=_yxF7gv_-ng

9.13.17  3:06 pm   so i began composing. I have a super great accompaniement that i'm really happy with, but i can't find for the life of me a good lead line. any tips?

     i think most of the time it seems to be better to do it the other way around, but not always. if you have a good groove/accompaniment that seems good on its own, i would suggest taking hints from what's going on there, and just taking the melody straight from something that's already happening. in other words, if it already sounds so good, then that means it probably is almost enough as it is, with not too much room for anything else unrelated. so perhaps try to find the most stand-out distinctive part about it, and emphasize it more. or, another option, if there happens to be an obvious space or gap anywhere, work with that space. it seems like if what you have already seems good, as you said, then you should be very gentle when 'adding' anything
